summary: Email correspondence between attorney Robert Glassman and an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding clarification of a witness's memory about attending a Lion King performance with Jeffrey Epstein. The discussion centers on whether the witness saw the Broadway play (which debuted in 1997) or the movie (1994) to help establish a timeline of her visits to New York.

persons.name: Robert Glassman
persons.context: Attorney at Panish Shea & Boyle LLP corresponding with a federal prosecutor about a witness's recollection of an event involving Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as having bragged about being good friends with Julie Taymor and providing amazing seats to a Lion King performance.

persons.name: Julie Taymor
persons.context: Referenced as a friend of Jeffrey Epstein who allegedly provided seats to the Lion King performance.

connections.description: Epstein bragged about being good friends with Julie Taymor, according to the witness's recollection.
Glassman is discussing a witness's account involving Epstein, indicating a legal or investigative connection.

events.title: Lion King Broadway debut
events.description: The Lion King musical first came out on Broadway.

events.title: Lion King movie release
events.description: The Lion King animated movie was released and was in theaters through approximately spring 1995.

keyFacts: A witness recalled attending a Lion King performance with Jeffrey Epstein, who bragged about being good friends with director Julie Taymor and having amazing first-row mezzanine seats she provided.
Prosecutors are trying to determine if the witness saw the Broadway play (debut 1997) or the movie (1994) to establish a timeline of her visits to New York.
The correspondence indicates ongoing investigation into witness accounts and timeline verification related to Epstein's activities.
The email exchange occurred in March 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic, with references to 'the world imploded' and health concerns.
